qas.question: What happened in northern Italy during the 1100's?

context: In the Roman Catholic Church, <a0_0><b5_0>obstinate and willful manifest heresy<b5_0/><a0_0/> is considered to spiritually cut one off from the Church, even before excommunication is incurred. <a1_0>The Codex Justinianus<a1_0/> (1:5:12) defines "everyone who is not devoted to the Catholic Church and to our Orthodox holy Faith" a heretic. The Church had always dealt harshly with strands of Christianity that it considered heretical, but before the <b6_0>11th century<b6_0/> these tended to centre around individual preachers or small localised sects, like <a2_0>Arianism, Pelagianism, Donatism, Marcionism and Montanism<a2_0/>. The diffusion of the almost <b7_0>Manichaean sect of <a3_0>Paulicians<b7_0/><a3_0/> westwards gave birth to the famous 11th and 12th century heresies of Western Europe. The first one was that of Bogomils in modern day Bosnia, a sort of sanctuary between Eastern and Western Christianity. By the 11th century, <b8_0>more organised groups such as the <a4_0>Patarini, the Dulcinians, the Waldensians and the Cathars<a4_0/> were beginning to appear<b8_0/> in the towns and cities of northern Italy, southern France and Flanders.
